def: Record of Rights (RoR). The conclusive record of ownership, cultivation, and revenue. Revised every 5 years (Quinquennial). Entries presumed true under Sec 45.
Field Book. Legal agricultural document detailing crop, area, soil type, and possession for each plot (Khasra No). Base for Girdawari.
Register of Cultivators/Tenants. Arranged by the holding of the cultivator (Kashtkar). Details who actually tills the land.
Harvest Inspection. Bi-annual crop inspection by Patwari (Oct 1st for Kharif, Mar 1st for Rabi) on Form No. 4.
Process of updating the Jamabandi to reflect changes in ownership (Sale, Inheritance, Mortgage). Entered in Register No. 6.
The 'Mother Map'. Original map drawn on thick paper during Settlement. Kept in the District Record Room (Muhafiz Khana).
Cloth copy of the Musavi map. Used by the Patwari in the field for rough work and daily measurements. Made of tracing cloth.
Supplementary map drawn when a Khasra number is divided (e.g., part sale). Shows new internal boundaries.
Account number of the OWNER (Malik) in the Jamabandi. Changes with every new Jamabandi preparation.
Land Revenue. The sovereign cash tax payable to the government for land ownership. Collected by the Lambardar.
Genealogical tree of landowners. Shows blood relations, caste, and inheritance history. Prepared during Settlement.
Village Administration Paper. Records village customs, rights to common land (Shamlat), and community rules.
Rain-fed land. Land dependent entirely on rainfall for cultivation. No artificial irrigation.
Canal irrigated land. Land irrigated by a canal (Kuhl). Assessed at higher revenue rates than Barani.
Old Fallow. Land that has remained uncultivated for 8 or more successive harvests (4 years).
Uncultivable land. Land occupied by roads, buildings, rivers, or mountains. Not assessed for revenue.
Village Common Land. Land belonging to the village community, used for grazing/paths/cremation grounds.
Daily Diary. Patwari records daily events (hailstorm, deaths, officer visits, epidemics) here. Form No. 2.
A copy of land records (Jamabandi/Mutation) given to the owner. 'Nakal' is the official certified copy.
'Min' means a part/portion of a Khasra number. 'Salam' means the whole field is included in the entry.
Land irrigated by a well (Chah). Common in valley areas like Una/Nalagarh.
The inhabited site of the village (Red Line / Lal Dora area). Traditionally exempt from revenue.
New Fallow. Land uncultivated for 4 successive harvests (2 years).
Map on wax-coated cloth. A durable copy of the Musavi used for tracing purposes.
Tri-junction pillar. A permanent stone marking where boundaries of three villages meet. Crucial for survey starting point.
Survey pillar. A fixed stone or concrete marker used as a reference point in field surveys.
Classification of land (e.g., Kishmi Awal, Kishmi Doyam) based on soil fertility/productivity.
The act or liability of paying land revenue.
Standing Record of Rights. The 'Permanent Settlement Record' prepared at the time of Settlement.
Occupancy Tenant. A tenant who has a permanent/heritable right to cultivate and cannot be evicted easily.
Tenant-at-will. A tenant who cultivates land year-to-year without permanent rights.
An owner who owns only the land in his possession but has NO share in the Shamlat (Common) land.
Rahin is the Mortgagor (Borrower who pledges land). Murtahin is the Mortgagee (Lender/Bank).
Rent paid as a share of the crop (e.g., 1/3rd or 1/4th) rather than cash.
Fixed rent paid in cash or kind (lump sum), regardless of the actual crop yield.
An image or tracing of the map (Shajra) provided to the applicant.
Fourth class land. Least fertile land usually on steep slopes.
Process of breaking/granting government waste land for cultivation. Governed by Nautor Rules 1968.
Village Note Book. Contains statistical data on crops, revenue, population, and livestock over time.
General Assembly of the village. Mutations must be attested here in public presence.
Correction of clerical errors in revenue records (spelling, totals) without full mutation proceedings.
The process of laying down boundary lines of a new revenue estate/village.
Field-wise detailed survey or measurement.
The circle of jurisdiction. E.g., Patwar Halqa (group of villages), Kanungo Halqa.
Cross-staff instrument used in surveying to set out right angles (90 degrees).
